After ending my first job out of college as a tax preparer for H&R Block, a call from my mother about a youth-run foundation to support activism in San Francisco sparked the idea of organizing my peers to try the same in Boston.

I had learned something about organizing from my activist mom who on most days could be found at her desk planning events or raising money for her favorite causes and candidates. I’d also picked up some organizing principles volunteering evenings after a day of H$R Block at a free tax clinic sponsored by Chelsea Fair Share. Fair Share’s leaders, Mark and Barbara Splain, taught me the value offering a service as part of earning trust and providing a chance to meet people who might join your cause. In their case an organization to build power among Chelsea’s low-income residents. It was a lesson I took with me for the rest of my career.

Philanthropy Years – Change not Charity

The Haymarket Foundation and the Funding Exchange

Having grown up more as a volunteer than a leader of campaigns, my first organizing project was the Haymarket People’s Fund. I started out with advice from local faith programs that made grants to community empowerment projects. Their unique approach included actively engaging members of the community in awarding the grants. At that time, I was studying for a master’s degree in American Studies at Goddard College. My final paper became a blueprint for creating a foundation. The Goddard course also inspired the its name, one that mixed the activist history I’d learned about the Haymarket Chicago protest for the eight-hour workday and Boston’s iconic 300-year-old Haymarket food market.

I followed the plan I created with my course instructor Steve Miller. First to explore how Boston foundations of the era worked, from the family foundations of the Cabot and Saltonstalls to the liberal churches and the social justice collaborative Resist. Then to meet with groups they suggested to explore the community organizing around Boston and eventually all of New England. All this became possible with my first hire, the wise and spirted Janet Axelrod and first full-time volunteer – my look alike twin to the outside world, David Crocker, assumed go to be heir to the “Betty Crocker” fortune, the made up brand of, Pillsbury’s competitor in the flour business.

Haymarket and the other alternative community funds that would form across the country sought to create a new generation of donors to support social change philanthropy. Under the banner of “Change not Charity,” we looked to invest in local organizations addressing the root causes of problems and taking steps towards more systemic and lasting solutions for the issues of the day. We hoped that our grants would give these local nonprofits the visibility and credibility that often results from association with the more established foundations.

Among those with inherited wealth that came of age in the social movements of the ’60s and ’70s, there was interest in funding those movements—but given the desire of many to remain anonymous, the challenge was to find them. I remembered the strategy of first offering a service, and found success in organizing gatherings for people with family wealth, providing a safe environment to discuss the personal issues related to coming into such wealth, including the impact on relationships, concerns about where their money came from, and how to have a conversation with their families or financial gatekeepers about using it to support activism.

Haymarket held its first local donor meetings in 1974 in partnership with the American Friends Service Committee. The Quaker network’s own donors had also asked for a personal retreat like this, with the assurances that the meeting would be private and free of fundraising. National gatherings began when our mentor, David Hunter of the Stern Family Fund, convened the donors he advised. Over time, the private meetings grew and would come to include activist leaders and guests who could offer their perspectives on social impact grantmaking. Through our formative years, we sponsored similar workshops and retreats—locally and nationally—that generated like-minded initiatives supporting a national trend towards social change grantmaking.

Along with the change in the types of grants came a shift in decision-making power. We broke from the private trustee model of grantmaking, where grants were approved by a board of family members or related legal and financial professionals, administered by a family office, opting instead for funding boards that would reflect the issues and communities where the grants were being made. It seemed more effective to have local leaders with grassroots organizing experience lead the process, and more in line with our values to have the process itself be an extension of community empowerment.

Haymarket’s founding board included activists like clerical worker Karen Nussbaum, who founded the organization 9to5, later made famous by the movie of the same name and Dolly Parton song; Walter Porter, Chair of the Boston association for minority firefighters; Robert Zevin, a lifelong activist and pioneer in the field of socially responsible investing; and Ann Froines, an advocate for women leaders. This model gave activists the opportunity to be grant makers Other public foundations with a similar mission soon adopted this approach.

In another break with traditional philanthropy, we went public. Because we were new and had to find new donors to join in our cause, we turned to marketing and outreach. In lieu of TV ads and the Internet, we gained recognition by having a presence at foundation gatherings, as well as publishing Robin Hood Was Right, inspired and edited by author Adam Hochschild. The book, published in 1977, featured our funds and attracted a national audience with appearances on the Oprah Winfrey and Phil Donahue shows and coverage from the New York Times to Parade magazine, Esquire, and The Wall Street Journal, and more.

In the wake of the publicity, young donors started 15 similar community foundations in areas like Atlanta, New York, Chicago, Minneapolis, and one in Los Angeles, Liberty Hill Foundation, founded by my sister Sarah Pillsbury. As we grew, it became clear that we would benefit from an association. Therefore, we created a national consortium called the Funding Exchange to support the growth of the local funds and to advance the conversation with other foundations around social change philanthropy.

This is not the history of a single foundation. It is the story of many similar efforts that built a movement to reshape philanthropy and create a community of foundations that shared a common social justice mission. Together we promoted the benefits of strategic grantmaking that sought to advance, over time, longer-term systemic approaches to the issues of the day.

  • For a history of the Funding Exchange, see the report Change, not Charity: A pioneer in social justice philanthropy.

Voter Engagement and Voting Rights

Among the foundations and nonprofits, I worked with, it was often said that the resources they had were only a fraction of what government could potentially provide.

The long-term success of any nonprofit organization depended on a partnership with a responsive government, both representative and accountable to the communities they served. In other words, a healthy and functioning democracy.

In the 1990s, this trend was going in the wrong direction. Voter turnout hovered at historic lows. More than half of eligible voters didn’t vote in midterms, and even fewer voted in local elections. Most of the absent voters were low-income, young, or first time voters new to the political process.

If the nonprofit sector wanted to strengthen democracy and have their voices heard, one way was to help the people they served to vote.

However, at the time many nonprofits mistakenly believed that their charitable status meant they couldn’t talk to their clients and constituents about voting. The IRS never said that. The Treasury Department only said in a single sentence that 501c3 nonprofits, which most nonprofits are, cannot support or oppose candidates for public office. A sentence was added in the 1950s by then Senator Lyndon Johnson to protect educational and charitable 501c3 nonprofits from the quicksand of partisan politics, thus safeguarding the tax deductions for supporters and their ability to receive foundation and government grants. IRS guidance clearly stated that public 501c3 nonprofits may do any amount of voter registration and education, including helping people participate and vote, as long as they did so on a nonpartisan basis.

The nonprofit sector had largely left untapped their inherent capacity — as trusted messengers, deeply rooted in their local communities — to increase voter participation among the people they served and engaged. They have day-to-day personal contact with potential voters often missed by candidates and campaigns more narrowly focused on attracting already likely voters. What’s more, their non-partisan approach tends to work better with new voters seeking help and information.

BostonVOTE, MassVOTE

After a mid-career year at the Harvard Kennedy School focused on electoral reform, I had my first chance to work at a democracy organization, the Boston-based Commonwealth Coalition. The coalition, originally set up to help progressive reform-oriented candidates run for office, added three nonpartisan programs: one challenging the role of money in state politics, one encouraging people to vote in local elections, and the other to support women’s political leadership. In 1993, I was recruited to run the money and politics program.

One of my first calls was from Emerson College student Malia Lazu, about her effort to hold a concert for democracy on Boston Common, the city’s downtown public park. Malia had heard about the concert I’d helped produce, headlined by Bob Marley, to benefit freedom movements in South Africa. When the city turned down her request for a permit because it feared problems with a multiracial audience, she volunteered to work for us at the coalition, and was soon directing the “Voter Power” initiative.

We shared our disillusion with the state of politics, particularly its troubled history of racial bias. Too often, election outcomes were decided in primaries in districts designed to favor mostly white incumbents. On Election Day voters had few, if any, choices on the ballot, and too little reason to vote.

Malia and I met with Boston nonprofit and foundation leaders about a pilot program specifically focused on training nonprofits to integrate nonpartisan voter and civic participation into programs they already offered. We hoped that this civic venture would bring higher turnout and might encourage more candidates to run, despite the odds, resulting in more competitive elections.

Voter Power became Boston VOTE. Starting in Boston, we recruited a board of nonprofit leaders from the city’s lower turnout neighborhoods, including Kim Janey who, two decades later, would become the city’s first African-American and woman mayor — herself a reflection of a changing political landscape.

Boston VOTE grew on the strength of its nonprofit outreach. By our second year, we had signed up more than 120 nonprofits serving the low turnout neighborhoods, including Dorchester, Roxbury, Mattapan, and Allston/Brighton. Boston VOTE reached out to service providers, neighborhood development organizations, advocacy organizations, community health centers, and the like to offer our nonpartisan voter engagement training.

We made a special effort to engage youth through our own Young Civic Leaders program which offered paid internships for high school students to work with local nonprofits and scheduled time to learn about lawmaking at the state house and city hall.

Many of these early partners developed their own voting initiatives, including:

  • Dunk the Vote: A multi-faceted civic empowerment group that had its start registering young black voters at youth basketball competitions. They went on to partner with us on a voter registration canvass called “Knock Across Boston.”

  • Mass Council for Human Service Providers: A founding partner, it had its own Care VOTE program to encourages human services employees, clients, consumers, board members and friends to register and vote.

  • Chinese Progressive Association (CPA): CPA tripled neighborhood turnout in its first city election. It became an advocate for fair redistricting and translation for ballots and for city hall hearings so all residents could fully participate.

  • Codman Square Health Center: One of the first health centers to participate in voter engagement. It used dedicated volunteers and staff to offer voter registration on site and at community events.

  • Madison Park Community Development Corporation: It hosted Rox Vote, a coalition of Roxbury-based organizations to help residents register and vote, host candidate forums, and promote youth civic leadership.

  • Mass Immigration and Refugee Advocacy Coalition: MIRA registered new voters at citizenship ceremonies and supported civic engagement and advocacy in partnership with its 130 organizational members, many of which also worked with MassVOTE.

  • Chelsea Human Services: An early partner, it organized community canvasses to promote voting and recruited young poll workers. Today the city’s large Latino population is fully represented on its city council and school committee.

  • Boston Election Department: We partnered on efforts to provide voter education in lower turnout areas and eventually came to sit on their community advisory board.

A Civic Uprising

More Voters

  • Turnout rose in city and state elections for each of our first five years in the 12 Boston neighborhoods with historically lowest voter participation.

  • Turnout growth averaged 30 percentage points compared to only 4% in the neighborhoods with already higher turnout.

More Candidates

As turnout rose in the city’s more diverse neighborhoods, so did the diversity of candidates. For the first time, in 2004 Boston elected a Latino candidate, Felix D. Arroyo, for a City Council at-large seat. The Boston Globe called it “an unprecedented leap in voting by minorities in Boston.”

The next year, Cape Verdean candidate Andrea Cabral became Boston’s sheriff. “Coming on the heels of last year’s victory by city councilor Arroyo, it signals a shifting landscape in Boston’s voting public. … a new era in Boston politics.” –Boston Herald

Boston VOTE Becomes MassVOTE

As interest grew in other cities such as Brockton, Lowell, Lawrence, and Worcester, we changed our name to MassVOTE and expanded our work statewide on voting and voting rights.

  • Civic Engagement Initiative: A collaboration, first with Boston foundations, grew to make grants to nonprofits for voter outreach in several metro areas in every region. Nonprofit participants tracked the people they contacted to evaluate their impact on turnout of new and infrequent voters.

  • Census and Redistricting: A collaboration with our largest statewide partners to increase census participation and monitor drawing of new election districts.

  • Voter Access and Fair Elections: In 2000, Massachusetts lacked options many states already had to vote early, use online registration, or let voters correct an error in their registration when they went to vote. To address these issues, we joined with nonpartisan organizations like the League of Women Voters, Common Cause, the Lawyers for Civil Rights, and the Mass Public Interest Group to form what became the Election Modernization Coalition. For more see a timeline of our recent achievements.

  • Taking on Racial Gerrymandering in Boston and other Cities: We weren’t lawyers, and had no plans to make our first foray into voting rights with a lawsuit, but when confronted with evidence of racial gerrymandering in Boston we took on the challenge. We had recently decided to purchase newly available redistricting software in order to monitor the make-up of the new 2002 district lines which the legislature was about to draw for Congress and themselves. We invited an attorney from the Lawyers for Civil Rights Boston to help us discuss its impact on the Boston neighborhoods where we were working. The story became one of racial gerrymandering in Boston, a federal lawsuit by black voters, the indictment and disbarment of the House speaker and, ultimately, justice for the targeted communities. (For the full story)

  • We continued our collaboration with the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights to challenge biased voting methods in Springfield and Lowell. For decades their winner-take-all, at-large voting method allowed a small group of white voters to retain full control of the City Council and School Committee. As a result, voters in a few neighborhoods determined the outcome of most all municipal seats, who got hired for city jobs, and which neighborhoods received services. In both cities, the plaintiffs we represented won their case for fair elections. (For more)

With thanks to Avi Green and Cheryl Clyburn Crawford who took over leadership of Mass VOTE in 2005. For more about its current work, visit its website

Boston VOTE staff photo the year founder Malia moved on to work on youth empowment with Harry Belafonte.

Nonprofit VOTE

In the Beginning

In 2005, it was not my intention to nationally replicate what MassVOTE had done in Massachusetts. The idea came from the Minnesota Council of Nonprofits’ Marcia Avner and Jon Pratt, who had run a similar program the year before. The timing worked well. At the same time, Catalina Ruiz-Healy, of the San Francisco Tides Foundation, gave MassVOTE an unsolicited grant of $50,000 to start similar initiatives in Oakland and other states. A similar grant came from a donor at the Funding Exchange to support nonprofit-led voter outreach in New Mexico and Pittsburgh.

What soon made it possible to reach out to the nonprofit sector nationally was a $100,000 renewable grant from Geri Mannion, Managing Director of Strengthening U.S. Democracy at the Carnegie Corporation foundation. Geri, already a supporter of the MN Council of Nonprofits, had long wanted an initiative to tap into what she saw as the “sleeping giant” of the growing nonprofit sector to increase voter turnout among underrepresented communities and strengthen democracy. She believed, as we did, that harnessing the everyday contact that community-based nonprofits had with people less likely to vote could increase their likelihood to vote and encourage their family and friends to do the same.

Activating the Nonprofit Sector

With offices in Minnesota and Boston, we reached out to other state nonprofit convenors to see if they’d join what we then called the Nonprofit Voter Engagement Network or NVEN. At the same time, we started to develop a strategy for what it would take to reach and engage a national audience.

State Partners

Nonprofit associations in Michigan, Ohio, North Carolina, Maine, and Louisiana were among the first to join NVEN, followed by nonprofit networks in Arizona and Greater Pittsburgh. Every year, NVEN members started meeting yearly in a different state to hone our trainings and to strategize how we could grow the network nationally. Among the most memorable was the 2008 meeting held in New Orleans. We were inspired not only by the music and the city’s ongoing fight to recover from Hurricane Katrina, but by our irrepressible state host, Ashley Herad of the Louisiana Alliance for Nonprofits who made us take a knee at any hint of indecision to move forward

State Partner list as of 2022

As more states joined, a geographically diverse subset of state partners joined a field program to evaluate our approach and impact. Each partner identified and managed a cohort of community-based nonprofits in their state to register voters and have them sign a pledge to vote onsite or at their events. They would track who registered and/or signed a pledge to vote. The data allowed us to measure our impact and learn lessons to share in our webinars and trainings.

National Partners

Soon, our first national networks began to join, led by the Alliance for Strong Families and Communities, a long-standing national network of settlement houses, neighborhood centers, human service agencies, and grassroots organizations focused on economic empowerment and neighborhood engagement. The second was the National Association of Community Health Clinics. Initiated by its advocacy director, Marc Wetherhorn. It established the Community Health Vote Program, with voter engagement resources and guidance shared with its 1,200 community health centers. They were followed by national partners like Goodwill Industries, Feeding America, and YWCA, all agreeing to incorporate voter engagement into their communications strategies and to promote our monthly webinars and online resources to their local and state affiliates.

Our national growth accelerated with the support of sector leaders like Tim Delaney and the National Council of Nonprofits, which convened state associations in the 50 states, and Diana Aviv and the advocacy team at the Independent Sector (IS), with its membership of national nonprofit networks and foundations. It was at an IS conference that we met Steve Taylor, vice president of United Way Worldwide. He asked us to create a voter engagement toolkit tailored for local United Ways. Their director of advocacy and policy, Lindsay Torrico, joined our leadership council. Sector convenors like the Council on Foundations and the Regional Associations of Grantmakers (now called the United Philanthropy Forum) also joined. We saw the results, as more of their affiliates signed up for a webinar training, joined us on National Voter Registration Day, and invited us to present at their national conference.

National Partner list as of 2022

Partnerships with Election Officials

In 2009, we were invited by the National Association of Secretaries of State and soon after the National Association of State Election Directors to be an official partner for the nonprofit sector. Their staff and members valued the nonpartisan guidance and training we gave nonprofits. We found our commitment to nonpartisanship opened doors, not just to the Secretaries of State, but to a wide variety of state and national partnerships and initiatives – the largest of which was National Voter Registration Day, and how we became one of the event’s founders and its primary manager.

National Voter Registration Day: A Celebration of Democracy

In 2012, Nonprofit VOTE joined the leading nonpartisan voter registration organizations to establish National Voter Registration Day. Celebrated on the fourth Tuesday of every September, it quickly gained momentum as a nonpartisan civic holiday celebrating our democracy. Each year, organizations, volunteers, and local election offices “hit the streets”—online and in the field—in a single day of coordinated field, technology, and media efforts. Support for the day comes from the largest nonpartisan registration groups, including media companies like Google, Reddit, MTV, Tumblr, and Facebook, and thousands of grassroots community partners. In 2020, more than 1.6 million voters registered or updated their registration on National Voter Registration Day. Along with the sponsors, 4,589 community partners signed up, recruiting 31,474 volunteers to conduct drives and stage events.

Now National Voter Registration Day started. (Insert Link here)

Trainings and Resources

The Trainings

When we began, nonprofits mainly knew what they couldn’t do around elections, but had little knowledge of what they could do on a nonpartisan basis to help people vote and educate candidates on their issues.

Our basic trainings explained the ban on partisan activities and when and how it started. The ban stems from a single sentence inserted into the tax code in 1954 by then Senator Lyndon Johnson. Johnson did so to protect 501c3 nonprofits from the quicksand of partisan politics, thus safeguarding the tax deductions allowed for donations to charitable and educational nonprofits for the long run. The IRS has repeatedly stated the ban did not exclude any non-partisan activity.

The trainings then highlighted the most common nonpartisan activities they could safely undertake, like voter registration, candidate forums, and reminders to vote. They also featured the benefits of voting for the nonprofit and the people they served, and offered strategies to help already busy organizations imagine how they could incorporate this work into their ongoing services, outreach, or events.

The Resources

Perhaps my greatest contribution in my years at Nonprofit VOTE was creating the stock materials and resources that became the foundation of our guidance and partner trainings. I had guidance from leading experts in the field, most notably our attorney John Pomeranz, and Greg Colvin, former co-chair of the American Bar Association Subcommittee on Political and Lobbying Activities of Exempt Organizations, as well as from the bolder advocacy program of the Alliance for Justice. Our online resources and monthly web trainings are accessed by nonprofits year round in all 50 states.

The Evaluation of Impact: Measuring How Nonprofits Help People Vote

Every year, Nonprofit VOTE sees an increase in the number of nonprofits signing up for its trainings and voter engagement on site and in their community. A 2020 survey by the Urban Institute found that one in five of the nation’s 875,000 registered nonprofits now do activities like voter registration and education.

But who are they reaching and is it helping increase voter participation? To find out, starting in 2012, Nonprofit VOTE enlisted a diverse set of state partners to manage a cohort of community-based nonprofits to track their voter engagement.

The participating nonprofits logged the people they registered to vote or who signed a voter pledge card and discussed their plan to vote. State voter files allowed us to do an independent analysis of the demographics and turnout rates of those we contacted to all other registered voters in the same area. The findings have consistently shown:

  1. The people the nonprofits reach are disproportionately younger (ages 18-25), lower income, and black, hispanic, or of color.

  2. The voter turnout for those we contacted varies from 5-15 points higher for the nonprofit voters, compared to all others. Nonprofits have had their largest impact on raising turnout in midterms.

  3. Turnout increases are highest among those least expected to vote, based on their demographics and voting history.

See sample research. Engaging New Voters 2018

Voter Engagement and Voting Rights

Among the foundations and nonprofits, I worked with, it was often said that the resources they had were only a fraction of what government could potentially provide.

The long-term success of any nonprofit organization depended on a partnership with a responsive government, both representative and accountable to the communities they served. In other words, a healthy and functioning democracy.

In the 1990s, this trend was going in the wrong direction. Voter turnout hovered at historic lows. More than half of eligible voters didn’t vote in midterms, and even fewer voted in local elections. Most of the absent voters were low-income, young, or first time voters new to the political process.

If the nonprofit sector wanted to strengthen democracy and have their voices heard, one way was to help the people they served to vote.

However, at the time many nonprofits mistakenly believed that their charitable status meant they couldn’t talk to their clients and constituents about voting. The IRS never said that. The Treasury Department only said in a single sentence that 501c3 nonprofits, which most nonprofits are, cannot support or oppose candidates for public office. A sentence was added in the 1950s by then Senator Lyndon Johnson to protect educational and charitable 501c3 nonprofits from the quicksand of partisan politics, thus safeguarding the tax deductions for supporters and their ability to receive foundation and government grants. IRS guidance clearly stated that public 501c3 nonprofits may do any amount of voter registration and education, including helping people participate and vote, as long as they did so on a nonpartisan basis.

The nonprofit sector had largely left untapped their inherent capacity — as trusted messengers, deeply rooted in their local communities — to increase voter participation among the people they served and engaged. They have day-to-day personal contact with potential voters often missed by candidates and campaigns more narrowly focused on attracting already likely voters. What’s more, their non-partisan approach tends to work better with new voters seeking help and information.

BostonVOTE, MassVOTE

After a mid-career year at the Harvard Kennedy School focused on electoral reform, I had my first chance to work at a democracy organization, the Boston-based Commonwealth Coalition. The coalition, originally set up to help progressive reform-oriented candidates run for office, added three nonpartisan programs: one challenging the role of money in state politics, one encouraging people to vote in local elections, and the other to support women’s political leadership. In 1993, I was recruited to run the money and politics program.

One of my first calls was from Emerson College student Malia Lazu, about her effort to hold a concert for democracy on Boston Common, the city’s downtown public park. Malia had heard about the concert I’d helped produce, headlined by Bob Marley, to benefit freedom movements in South Africa. When the city turned down her request for a permit because it feared problems with a multiracial audience, she volunteered to work for us at the coalition, and was soon directing the “Voter Power” initiative.

We shared our disillusion with the state of politics, particularly its troubled history of racial bias. Too often, election outcomes were decided in primaries in districts designed to favor mostly white incumbents. On Election Day voters had few, if any, choices on the ballot, and too little reason to vote.

Malia and I met with Boston nonprofit and foundation leaders about a pilot program specifically focused on training nonprofits to integrate nonpartisan voter and civic participation into programs they already offered. We hoped that this civic venture would bring higher turnout and might encourage more candidates to run, despite the odds, resulting in more competitive elections.

Voter Power became Boston VOTE. Starting in Boston, we recruited a board of nonprofit leaders from the city’s lower turnout neighborhoods, including Kim Janey who, two decades later, would become the city’s first African-American and woman mayor — herself a reflection of a changing political landscape.

Boston VOTE grew on the strength of its nonprofit outreach. By our second year, we had signed up more than 120 nonprofits serving the low turnout neighborhoods, including Dorchester, Roxbury, Mattapan, and Allston/Brighton. Boston VOTE reached out to service providers, neighborhood development organizations, advocacy organizations, community health centers, and the like to offer our nonpartisan voter engagement training.

We made a special effort to engage youth through our own Young Civic Leaders program which offered paid internships for high school students to work with local nonprofits and scheduled time to learn about lawmaking at the state house and city hall.

Many of these early partners developed their own voting initiatives, including:

  • Dunk the Vote: A multi-faceted civic empowerment group that had its start registering young black voters at youth basketball competitions. They went on to partner with us on a voter registration canvass called “Knock Across Boston.”

  • Mass Council for Human Service Providers: A founding partner, it had its own Care VOTE program to encourages human services employees, clients, consumers, board members and friends to register and vote.

  • Chinese Progressive Association (CPA): CPA tripled neighborhood turnout in its first city election. It became an advocate for fair redistricting and translation for ballots and for city hall hearings so all residents could fully participate.

  • Codman Square Health Center: One of the first health centers to participate in voter engagement. It used dedicated volunteers and staff to offer voter registration on site and at community events.

  • Madison Park Community Development Corporation: It hosted Rox Vote, a coalition of Roxbury-based organizations to help residents register and vote, host candidate forums, and promote youth civic leadership.

  • Mass Immigration and Refugee Advocacy Coalition: MIRA registered new voters at citizenship ceremonies and supported civic engagement and advocacy in partnership with its 130 organizational members, many of which also worked with MassVOTE.

  • Chelsea Human Services: An early partner, it organized community canvasses to promote voting and recruited young poll workers. Today the city’s large Latino population is fully represented on its city council and school committee.

  • Boston Election Department: We partnered on efforts to provide voter education in lower turnout areas and eventually came to sit on their community advisory board.

A Civic Uprising

More Voters

  • Turnout rose in city and state elections for each of our first five years in the 12 Boston neighborhoods with historically lowest voter participation.

  • Turnout growth averaged 30 percentage points compared to only 4% in the neighborhoods with already higher turnout.

More Candidates

As turnout rose in the city’s more diverse neighborhoods, so did the diversity of candidates. For the first time, in 2004 Boston elected a Latino candidate, Felix D. Arroyo, for a City Council at-large seat. The Boston Globe called it “an unprecedented leap in voting by minorities in Boston.”

The next year, Cape Verdean candidate Andrea Cabral became Boston’s sheriff. “Coming on the heels of last year’s victory by city councilor Arroyo, it signals a shifting landscape in Boston’s voting public. … a new era in Boston politics.” –Boston Herald

Boston VOTE Becomes MassVOTE

As interest grew in other cities such as Brockton, Lowell, Lawrence, and Worcester, we changed our name to MassVOTE and expanded our work statewide on voting and voting rights.

  • Census and Redistricting: A collaboration with our largest statewide partners to increase census participation and monitor drawing of new election districts.

  • Voter Access and Fair Elections: In 2000, Massachusetts lacked options many states already had to vote early, use online registration, or let voters correct an error in their registration when they went to vote. To address these issues, we joined with nonpartisan organizations like the League of Women Voters, Common Cause, the Lawyers for Civil Rights, and the Mass Public Interest Group to form what became the Election Modernization Coalition. For more see a timeline of our recent achievements.

  • Taking on Racial Gerrymandering in Boston and other Cities: We weren’t lawyers, and had no plans to make our first foray into voting rights with a lawsuit, but when confronted with evidence of racial gerrymandering in Boston we took on the challenge. We had recently decided to purchase newly available redistricting software in order to monitor the make-up of the new 2002 district lines which the legislature was about to draw for Congress and themselves. We invited an attorney from the Lawyers for Civil Rights Boston to help us discuss its impact on the Boston neighborhoods where we were working. The story became one of racial gerrymandering in Boston, a federal lawsuit by black voters, the indictment and disbarment of the House speaker and, ultimately, justice for the targeted communities. (For the full story)

  • We continued our collaboration with the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights to challenge biased voting methods in Springfield and Lowell. For decades their winner-take-all, at-large voting method allowed a small group of white voters to retain full control of the City Council and School Committee. As a result, voters in a few neighborhoods determined the outcome of most all municipal seats, who got hired for city jobs, and which neighborhoods received services. In both cities, the plaintiffs we represented won their case for fair elections. (For more)

Nonprofit VOTE

In the Beginning

In 2005, it was not my intention to nationally replicate what MassVOTE had done in Massachusetts. The idea came from the Minnesota Council of Nonprofits’ Marcia Avner and Jon Pratt, who had run a similar program the year before. The timing worked well. At the same time, Catalina Ruiz-Healy, of the San Francisco Tides Foundation, gave MassVOTE an unsolicited grant of $50,000 to start similar initiatives in Oakland and other states. A similar grant came from a donor at the Funding Exchange to support nonprofit-led voter outreach in New Mexico and Pittsburgh.

What soon made it possible to reach out to the nonprofit sector nationally was a $100,000 renewable grant from Geri Mannion, Managing Director of Strengthening U.S. Democracy at the Carnegie Corporation foundation. Geri, already a supporter of the MN Council of Nonprofits, had long wanted an initiative to tap into what she saw as the “sleeping giant” of the growing nonprofit sector to increase voter turnout among underrepresented communities and strengthen democracy. National Partner list as of 2022

Support for the day comes from the largest nonpartisan registration groups, including media companies like Google, Reddit, MTV, Tumblr, and Facebook, and thousands of grassroots community partners. In 2020, more than 1.6 million voters registered or updated their registration on National Voter Registration Day. Along with the sponsors, 4,589 community partners signed up, recruiting 31,474 volunteers to conduct drives and stage events.

Trainings and Resources

The Trainings

When we began, nonprofits mainly knew what they couldn’t do around elections, but had little knowledge of what they could do on a nonpartisan basis to help people vote and educate candidates on their issues.

Our basic trainings explained the ban on partisan activities and when and how it started. The ban stems from a single sentence inserted into the tax code in 1954 by then Senator Lyndon Johnson. Johnson did so to protect 501c3 nonprofits from the quicksand of partisan politics, thus safeguarding the tax deductions allowed for donations to charitable and educational nonprofits for the long run. The IRS has repeatedly stated the ban did not exclude any non-partisan activity.

The trainings then highlighted the most common nonpartisan activities they could safely undertake, like voter registration, candidate forums, and reminders to vote. They also featured the benefits of voting for the nonprofit and the people they served, and offered strategies to help already busy organizations imagine how they could incorporate this work into their ongoing services, outreach, or events.

The Resources

Perhaps my greatest contribution in my years at Nonprofit VOTE was creating the stock materials and resources that became the foundation of our guidance and partner trainings. I had guidance from leading experts in the field, most notably our attorney John Pomeranz, and Greg Colvin, former co-chair of the American Bar Association Subcommittee on Political and Lobbying Activities of Exempt Organizations, as well as from the bolder advocacy program of the Alliance for Justice. Our online resources and monthly web trainings are accessed by nonprofits year round in all 50 states.

The Evaluation of Impact: Measuring How Nonprofits Help People Vote

Every year, Nonprofit VOTE sees an increase in the number of nonprofits signing up for its trainings and voter engagement on site and in their community. A 2020 survey by the Urban Institute found that one in five of the nation’s 875,000 registered nonprofits now do activities like voter registration and education.

But who are they reaching and is it helping increase voter participation? To find out, starting in 2012, Nonprofit VOTE enlisted a diverse set of state partners to manage a cohort of community-based nonprofits to track their voter engagement.

The participating nonprofits logged the people they registered to vote or who signed a voter pledge card and discussed their plan to vote. State voter files allowed us to do an independent analysis of the demographics and turnout rates of those we contacted to all other registered voters in the same area. The findings have consistently shown:

  1. The people the nonprofits reach are disproportionately younger (ages 18-25), lower income, and black, hispanic, or of color.

  2. The voter turnout for those we contacted varies from 5-15 points higher for the nonprofit voters, compared to all others. Nonprofits have had their largest impact on raising turnout in midterms.

  3. Turnout increases are highest among those least expected to vote, based on their demographics and voting history.

 *   Mass Immigration and Refugee Advocacy Coalition: MIRA
   registered new voters at citizenship ceremonies and supported civic
   engagement and advocacy in partnership with its 130 organizational
   members, many of which also worked with MassVOTE. 
   
   
 *   Chelsea Human Services: An early partner, it organized
   community canvasses to promote voting and recruited young poll workers.
   Today the city’s large Latino population is fully represented on its city
   council and school committee. 
   
   
 *   Boston Election Department: We partnered on efforts to
   provide voter education in lower turnout areas and eventually came to sit
   on their community advisory board. 
   
   

A Civic Uprising
More Voters
Percent increase in voters casting ballots compared to the same election 4
years before  *  Turnout rose in city and state elections for each of our first five years
   in the 12 Boston neighborhoods with historically lowest voter
   participation. 
   
   
 *  Turnout growth averaged 30 percentage points compared to only 4% in the
   neighborhoods with already higher turnout. 
   
   

More Candidates
Felix D. ArroyoAs turnout rose in the city’s more diverse neighborhoods, so did
the diversity
of candidates. For the first time, in 2004 Boston elected a Latino candidate,
Felix D. Arroyo, for a City Council at-large seat. The Boston Globe called it
“an unprecedented leap in voting by minorities in Boston.”

Andrea J. CabralThe next year, Cape Verdean candidate Andrea Cabral became
Boston’s sheriff.
“Coming on the heels of last year’s victory by city councilor Arroyo, it
signals a shifting landscape in Boston’s voting public. … a new era in Boston
politics.” –Boston Herald

Boston VOTE Becomes MassVOTE
As interest grew in other cities such as Brockton, Lowell, Lawrence, and
Worcester, we changed our name to MassVOTE and expanded our
work statewide on voting and voting rights.

MassVOTE Staff 2004: Front (left to right): Treena Reney Bryant, Aitya
Dengleben, Back (left to right) George Pillsbury, Rose Arruda, Jeff Arp, Gibran
Rivera  * 
 *   Civic Engagement Initiative: A collaboration, first with
   Boston foundations, grew to make grants to nonprofits for voter outreach
   in several metro areas in every region. Nonprofit participants tracked the
   people they contacted to evaluate their impact on turnout of new and
   infrequent voters. 
   
   
 *   Census and Redistricting: A collaboration with our
   largest statewide partners to increase census participation and monitor
   drawing of new election districts. 
   
   
 *  MassVOTE Co-Directors Cheryl Clyburn Crawford and Avi Green join Governor
   Deval Patrick at bill signing for online voter registration, post-election
   audits, pre-registration to vote of 16 and 17-year-olds, and early voting,
   2014 
 *   Voter Access and Fair Elections: In 2000, Massachusetts
   lacked options many states already had to vote early, use online
   registration, or let voters correct an error in their registration when
   they went to vote. To address these issues, we joined with nonpartisan
   organizations like the League of Women Voters, Common Cause, the Lawyers
   for Civil Rights, and the Mass Public Interest Group to form what became
   the Election Modernization Coalition. For more see a timeline
   [https://www.massvote.org/history-and-achievements]of our recent
   achievements. 
   
   
 *  House Speaker Tom Finneran going over new district lines in his home
   basement. Photo by Dorchester Community News 
 *   Taking on Racial Gerrymandering in Boston and other Cities:We weren’t
   lawyers, and had no plans to make our first foray into
   voting rights with a lawsuit, but when confronted with evidence of racial
   gerrymandering in Boston we took on the challenge. We had recently decided
   to
   purchase newly available redistricting software in order to monitor the
   make-up of the new 2002 district lines which the legislature was about to
   draw for Congress and themselves. We invited an attorney from the Lawyers
   for Civil Rights Boston to help us discuss its impact on the Boston
   neighborhoods where we were working. The story became one of racial
   gerrymandering in Boston, a federal lawsuit by black voters, the
   indictment and disbarment of the House speaker and, ultimately, justice
   for the targeted communities. (For the full story) 
   
   
 *  
 *  We continued our collaboration with the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights
   to challenge
   biased voting methods in Springfield and Lowell. For decades their
   winner-take-all, at-large voting method allowed a small group of white
   voters to retain full control of the City Council and School Committee. As
   a result, voters in a few neighborhoods determined the outcome of
   most all municipal seats, who got hired for city jobs, and which
   neighborhoods received services. In both cities, the plaintiffs we
   represented won their case for fair elections. (For more) 
   
   


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

With thanks to Avi Green [https://www.linkedin.com/in/avigreen/]and Cheryl
Clyburn Crawford [https://www.massvote.org/staff]who took over leadership of
Mass VOTE in 2005. For more about its current
work, visit its website [https://www.massvote.org/]

Boston VOTE staff photo the year founder Malia moved on to work on youth
empowment with Harry Belafonte.

Nonprofit VOTE
In the Beginning
In 2005, it was not my intention to nationally replicate what MassVOTE had
done in Massachusetts. The idea came from the Minnesota Council of
Nonprofits’ Marcia Avner and Jon Pratt, who had run a similar program
the year before. The timing worked well. At the same time, Catalina
Ruiz-Healy, of the San Francisco Tides Foundation, gave MassVOTE an
unsolicited grant of $50,000 to start similar initiatives in Oakland and other
states. A similar grant came from a donor at the Funding Exchange to support
nonprofit-led voter outreach in New Mexico and Pittsburgh.

> When it Comes to Voting Rights, Philanthropy Needs to Act Like Every Day Is
Election Day 
Geri Mannion, April 2021
[https://www.philanthropy.com/article/when-it-comes-to-voting-rights-philanthropy-needs-to-act-like-every-day-is-election-day]
 What soon made it possible to reach out to the nonprofit sector nationally was
a $100,000 renewable grant from Geri Mannion, Managing Director of
Strengthening U.S. Democracy at the Carnegie Corporation foundation. Geri,
already a supporter of the MN Council of Nonprofits, had long wanted an
initiative to tap into what she saw as the “sleeping giant” of the
growing nonprofit sector to increase voter turnout among underrepresented
communities and strengthen democracy. She believed, as we did, that harnessing
the everyday contact that community-based nonprofits had with people less
likely to vote could increase their likelihood to vote and encourage their
family and friends to do the same.

Activating the Nonprofit Sector
With offices in Minnesota and Boston, we reached out to other state
nonprofit convenors to see if they’d join what we then called the
Nonprofit Voter Engagement Network or NVEN. At the same time, we started to
develop a strategy for what it would take to reach and engage a national
audience.

State Partners
Nonprofit associations in Michigan, Ohio, North Carolina, Maine, and Louisiana
were among the first to join NVEN, followed by nonprofit networks in Arizona
and Greater Pittsburgh. Every year, NVEN members started meeting yearly in a
different state to hone our trainings and to strategize how we could grow the
network nationally. Among the most memorable was the 2008 meeting held in New
Orleans. We were inspired not only by the music and the city’s ongoing
fight to recover from Hurricane Katrina, but by our irrepressible state host,
Ashley Herad of the Louisiana Alliance for Nonprofits who made us take a knee
at any hint of indecision to move forward

 State Partner list as of 2022
[https://www.nonprofitvote.org/about-state-partners/]

As more states joined, a geographically diverse subset of state partners
joined a field program to evaluate our approach and impact. Each partner
identified and managed a cohort of community-based nonprofits in their state
to register voters and have them sign a pledge to vote onsite or at their
events. They would track who registered and/or signed a pledge to vote. The
data allowed us to measure our impact and learn lessons to share in our
webinars and trainings.

National Partners
Soon, our first national networks began to join, led by the Alliance for Strong
Families and Communities [https://www.alliance1.org/], a long-standing national
network of settlement houses, neighborhood centers, human service agencies,
and grassroots organizations focused on economic empowerment and
neighborhood engagement. The second was the National Association of Community
Health Clinics [https://www.hcadvocacy.org/]. Initiated by its advocacy
director, Marc Wetherhorn. It established the Community Health Vote Program,
with voter engagement resources and guidance shared with its 1,200 community
health centers. They were followed by national partners like Goodwill
Industries, Feeding America, and YWCA, all agreeing to incorporate voter
engagement into their communications strategies and to promote our monthly
webinars and online resources to their local and state affiliates.

Our national growth accelerated with the support of sector leaders like
Tim Delaney and the National Council of Nonprofits
[https://www.councilofnonprofits.org/trends-policy-issues/protecting-nonprofit-nonpartisanship]
, which convened state associations in the 50
states, and Diana Aviv and the advocacy team at the Independent Sector (IS)
[https://independentsector.org/], with its membership of national nonprofit
networks
and foundations. It was at an IS conference that we met Steve Taylor, vice
president of United Way Worldwide [https://www.unitedway.org/]. He asked us to
create a voter engagement toolkit
tailored for local United Ways. Their director of advocacy and policy,
Lindsay Torrico, joined our leadership council. Sector convenors like the 
Council on Foundations and the Regional Associations of Grantmakers (now
called the United Philanthropy Forum) also joined. We saw the results, as
more of their affiliates signed up for a webinar training, joined us on
National Voter Registration Day, and invited us to present at their national
conference.

 National Partner list as of 2022
[https://www.nonprofitvote.org/about-national-partners/]

Partnerships with Election Officials
In 2009, we were invited by the National Association of Secretaries of State
[https://www.nass.org/] and soon after the National Association of State
Election Directors [https://www.nased.org/] to be an official partner
for the nonprofit sector. Their staff and members valued the nonpartisan
guidance and training we gave nonprofits. We found our commitment to
nonpartisanship opened doors, not just to the Secretaries of State, but to a
wide variety of state and national partnerships and initiatives – the
largest of which was National Voter Registration Day, and how we became one
of the event’s founders and its primary manager.

National Voter Registration Day: A Celebration of Democracy
In 2012, Nonprofit VOTE joined the leading nonpartisan voter registration
organizations to establish National Voter Registration Day. Celebrated on the
fourth Tuesday of every September, it quickly gained momentum as a nonpartisan
civic holiday celebrating our democracy. Each year, organizations, volunteers,
and local election offices “hit the streets”—online and in
the field—in a single day of coordinated field, technology, and media
efforts. Support for the day comes from the largest nonpartisan registration
groups, including media companies like Google, Reddit, MTV, Tumblr, and
Facebook, and thousands of grassroots community partners. In 2020, more than
1.6 million voters registered or updated their registration on National Voter
Registration Day. Along with the sponsors, 4,589 community partners signed up,
recruiting 31,474 volunteers to conduct drives and stage events.

Now National Voter Registration Day started. (Insert Link here)

Trainings and Resources
The Trainings
When we began, nonprofits mainly knew what they couldn’t do around elections,
but had little knowledge of what
they could do on a nonpartisan basis to help people vote and educate
candidates on their issues.

> A 501(c)(3 tax-exempt organization may not intervene in any political
campaign on behalf of (or in opposition to) any candidate for public
office. 
blah blah Our basic trainings explained the ban on partisan activities and when
and how
it started. The ban stems from a single sentence inserted into the tax code in
1954 by then Senator Lyndon Johnson. Johnson did so to protect 501c3 nonprofits
[https://www.councilofnonprofits.org/trends-policy-issues/protecting-nonprofit-nonpartisanship] 
from the quicksand of partisan politics, thus
safeguarding the tax deductions allowed for donations to charitable and
educational nonprofits for the long run. The IRS has repeatedly stated the
ban did not exclude any non-partisan activity.

The trainings then highlighted the most common nonpartisan activities they
could safely undertake, like voter registration, candidate forums, and
reminders to vote. They also featured the benefits of voting for the nonprofit
and the people they served, and offered strategies to help already busy
organizations imagine how they could incorporate this work into their ongoing
services, outreach, or events.

The Resources
Perhaps my greatest contribution in my years at Nonprofit VOTE was creating
the stock materials and resources that became the foundation of our guidance
and partner trainings. I had guidance from leading experts in the field, most
notably our attorney John Pomeranz
[https://www.linkedin.com/in/john-pomeranz-5719224/], and Greg Colvin
[https://www.adlercolvin.com/gregory-l-colvin-2/], former co-chair of the 
American Bar Association Subcommittee
on Political and Lobbying Activities of Exempt Organizations
[https://www.americanbar.org/groups/taxation/committees_task_forces/exempt_orgs/]
, as well as
from the bolder advocacy program of the Alliance for Justice. Our online
resources and monthly web trainings are accessed by nonprofits year round in
all 50 states.

The Evaluation of Impact: Measuring How Nonprofits Help People Vote
Every year, Nonprofit VOTE sees an increase in the number of nonprofits
signing up for its trainings and voter engagement on site and in their
community. A 2020 survey by the Urban Institute found that one in five of the
nation’s 875,000 registered nonprofits now do activities like voter
registration and education.

But who are they reaching and is it helping increase voter participation? To
find out, starting in 2012, Nonprofit VOTE enlisted a diverse set of state
partners to manage a cohort of community-based nonprofits to track their voter
engagement.

The participating nonprofits logged the people they registered to vote or who
signed a voter pledge card and discussed their plan to vote. State voter files
allowed us to do an independent analysis of the demographics and turnout rates
of those we contacted to all other registered voters in the same area. The
findings have consistently shown:

 1.  The people the nonprofits reach are disproportionately younger (ages
    18-25), lower income, and black, hispanic, or of color. 
    
    
 2.  The voter turnout for those we contacted varies from 5-15 points higher
    for the nonprofit voters, compared to all others. Nonprofits have had
    their largest impact on raising turnout in midterms. 
    
    
 3.  Turnout increases are highest among those least expected to vote, based on
    their demographics and voting history. 
    
    

 See sample research. Engaging New Voters 2018
[https://www.nonprofitvote.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/engaging-new-voters-2018.pdf]

{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

Born a brand name

I was born the son of Minnesotans George Sturgis Pillsbury and Sally Lucille (Whitney) Pillsbury in 1949, entering the world with a brand name passed down by my great grandfather Charles A. Pillsbury and his uncle, John S. Pillsbury. John was the first to leave the family homestead of Sutton, New Hampshire in search of new opportunities. In 1855, John first traveled to San Francisco, then backtracked to visit the settlement of Saint Anthony Falls along the Mississippi because it reminded him of the Merrimack River he had left behind in New England. He found opportunity in establishing a hardware store and later a flour mill in what would become Minneapolis.

Once the hardware store was up and running, he encouraged my grandfather Charles, who had studied the mills of Montreal, to join him. His nephew's assignment was to start and manage what became the first Pillsbury mill. Overcoming any number of challenges, from fires to finance, Charles always gave priority to investing in the health and education of the company’s employees. The fledgling enterprise found its way. What was originally the A-Mill is still marked by its landmark neon sign on the skyline of Minneapolis.

Growing up with this legacy, there was no way I could hide from the brand and all that came with it. This became more true when the Pillsbury company adopted the Dough Boy as its mascot, which left me with more than my share of "Are you related?" at the check-out counter and Dough Boy pokes and jokes.

Along with my family’s eventual success in Minnesota came the expectation of civic and community engagement, built on the values they brought with them from their life in New Hampshire and ancestors before. Values I was taught by my family and carried into my career in philanthropy and voter engagement - starting with a grant-making foundation for people of my generation to support social action and community organizing of the era. It was no surprise my ventures into philanthropy soon came with the nickname the “Dough Boy.”

My other brand was my parents, George and Sally Pillsbury. In their 56-year marriage as political and civic activists, they were hard to miss at any venue or gathering for community service or on the campaign trail. Except for two years in New York, they lived in and devoted their whole 90+ years to Minnesota.

My father (1922-2012), was born in his parents’ house west of Minneapolis on Lake Minnetonka. A graduate of Yale University and a U.S. Marine, he was the last in the family to work for the Pillsbury company, later serving 12 years in the Minnesota State Senate.

My mother (1924-2018), grew up in St. Cloud, a small city northwest of the Twin Cities. Having moved with her family to Lake Minnetonka not far from my father, she graduated Smith College and made a name for herself in community service and politics.

They both strived at every opportunity to promote the moderate Lincoln wing of the Republican party and its values. My father, well into his 80s at the time, was banned by the state party for supporting an Independent candidate.

Early years

My first memory of politics was joining my mother at the 1958 Minnesota Republican convention where teen entertainment was a hula hoop contest. Embarrassing but fun. It was the start of a steady flow of state and county conventions and campaigns run out of our basement or featured at the political booths of the state fair.

I joined her at the 1964 GOP national convention in San Francisco on behalf of moderate Pennsylvania Governor Bill Scranton against Barry Goldwater. At the time, His campaign helped move the far right to center stage. Then in 1968, in the wake of the explosive protests at Chicago's Democratic Convention, I went with a youth to Miami to support New York Governor Nelson Rockefeller against Richard Nixon. The busload of young Republicans included my sister Sarah. In distress of the party's choice, on our bus ride home our youth group issued a press release picked up (to our parents’ surprise) by the local papers endorsing the Democratic nominee, Senator Hubert Humphrey (MN).

I still had opportunities to work for Republican moderates. I wasn’t at home with either major party. Like my parents, I wished we had more parties to choose from.

College – 1968 - 2002

Before 1968 I saw politics only as what candidate to work for in the next election. This changed as I watched the issues of race and war tear the country apart. When I moved to live in the diverse working-class city of New Haven to enter college at Yale, I was drawn to life outside campus. More engaged by the community service work of the New Haven Black Panthers, and the anti-war protests. I didn't give up contesting elections, joining my brother to canvass for the peace campaign of New York's Al Lowenstein. I signed onto join the reform mayoral campaign to unseat New Haven's party machine.

At the same time, I made my first ever political donation. In a short-lived attempt at anonymity, I left $200 in cash at the office at the office of the Black Panthers for their free breakfast, health, and community education programs. I let them have my car to help residents visit family members in prison. This side of my volunteer work earned me a substantial FBI file informed by the New Haven police tapping my dorm room phone. A few years later a letter arrived with a $1,000 check from a class action suit I signed onto against the New Haven PD.

I had some memorable college classes, but maybe because of the family I grew up with, I learned the most from what happened outside them. My friendship with the Panther leaders taught me lessons in personal relations across different backgrounds. As did two weeks on a picket line with the dining hall and janitorial workers. Yale going co-ed in my sophomore year (I'd been at boys' schools since 3rd grade), brought a new connection and appreciation of strong women like my mother and two sisters. In 1969 outnumbered by eight to one, 455 women brought feminism to campus, interrupting a men's club of 265 years.

Haymarket Foundation

My first job after college was doing a season of tax preparation for H&R Block. I had graduated a semester late, and had taken their tax prep course in the fall so I would have a job in January when I moved northeast to Cambridge. In my Central Square office, I had a chance to learn the ins and outs of deductions and help area residents like presidential biographer Doris Kearns Goodwin and future author, Joe Klein, then a columnist for city's alternative weekly, The Real Paper. In the evenings I volunteered at a free tax clinic for low-income residents sponsored by Fair Share, a community group in neighboring Chelsea.

In 1972, As the tax season wound down and I wondered what was next, I got a timely call from my mother. She had just met someone my age at the national meeting of the Council of Foundations, held that year in Minneapolis. As was her nature, she introduced herself to the youngest person there, the one with the pony tail and sneakers. Obie Benz, a Sunbeam Bread heir, had started the Vanguard Foundation in San Francisco as a way for young people with inherited wealth to support social change initiatives in the Bay area. Urged on by my college friend, Lynn Rosengarten, I decided to give it a try in Boston. We traveled west to meet Obie and Vanguard volunteer Anne Hess. Annie had experience from a family foundation, the Stern Family Fund. At the time, it was one of the few national foundations to focus on supporting activism. Its director David Hunter would be invaluable in helping us get started.

New to Boston and with less money than people expected from my last name, I had to find others like myself to join in. In time they did, and the Haymarket Foundation started at 2 Holyoke Street in Harvard Square. It offered an opportunity for young donors in New England to support organizing and community empowerment. Empowerment included sharing the power to make grants with experienced local leaders. Haymarket also gave its donors, many of whom remained anonymous, a chance to meet with others like themselves to discuss personal issues related to inherited wealth and living out the values that drew them to Haymarket in the first place.

Funding Exchange

We first reached a national audience with the publication of our book, Robin Hood Was Right, a gift-giving guide to funding social change. Talk show hosts Phil Donahue and Oprah Winfrey invited us on to talk about the book, and, in a friendly way, ask questions like why we were supporting causes that could well reduce our wealth advantage.

In the wake of the publicity, young donors started similar community foundations in Atlanta, New York, Chicago, Minneapolis and elsewhere. We created a national consortium called the Funding Exchange to support their growth and, as a national network engage other foundations in a conversation about social change philanthropy and the value of more diversity to their boards.

The Film Fund

Our foundations lacked the expertise to fund the media arts, like documentary films that could dramatize the issues we addressed. In response, my Haymarket co-founder David Crocker and I joined producer Miles Mogulescu to create The Film Fund, as a vehicle to support and give visibility to social issue documentaries such as ones we'd invested in individually: 1976 Oscar-winning, Harlan County USA and 1977 Oscar nominee Union Maids.

We recruited a panel of experienced filmmakers including Barbara Kopple and Julia Reichert, the directors of the above films, and renowned cinematographer Haskell Wexler to evaluate promising documentaries already in production and in need of a boost or finishing costs. The Film Fund had a ten-year life, contributing with others to the emergence of the independent documentary film landscape we see today.

By the 1990s, the nonprofit and philanthropic sector had grown exponentially. Many more traditional community and private foundations, as well as new ones similar to ours, had incorporated a more systemic approach to addressing social issues through advocacy and community building. At the same time, it became more evident that progress on any issue depended on a democracy and government that worked and had the trust and participation of its citizens. That brought me back to my family roots in good government and elections.

In 1994, a mid-career year program at the Harvard Kennedy School gave me an opportunity to explore best practices for elections among the states and in countries similar to ours. My other brand was my parents, George and Sally Pillsbury. In their 56-year marriage as political and civic activists, they were hard to miss at any venue or gathering for community service or on the campaign trail. Before 1968 I saw politics only as what candidate to work for in the next election. This changed as I watched the issues of race and war tear the country apart. When I moved to live in the diverse working-class city of New Haven to enter college at Yale, I was drawn to life outside campus. 1. How do I see the automatically generated sitemap? Do I have to do that from Google Search console? Use /sitemap.xml
  2. Should the "Family History" page be a route that leads to a tag archive page? The tag archive pages have a heading and custom content and could be customized further as needed. Underneath the tag archive page's header area is a list of blog posts with that tag.

  5. asdfasdf

Bugs

  1. Problems with routes in the Portal settings. Regardless of whether a user is signed in, clicking on either the monthly or yearly sign up links opens a popup with the message "Failed to sign up, please try again." Attempting to close that popup shows a loading icon that spins forever. Clicking on the background makes the popup disappear. Here are the links: Sign up/Monthly https://www.georgepillsbury.com/#/portal/signup/monthly Sign up/Yearly  https://www.georgepillsbury.com/#/portal/signup/yearly
  2. Problems with routes in the portal settings: The /signup/free link behaves differently. When signed in, clicking on it shows the user's account details popup. When not signed in, clicking on it shows the sign up popup.
  3. Problems with routes in the portal settings: When not signed in, the /account/ link opens the login popup. When signed in the /account/ link opens a popup with name, email, and subscriptions and also allows you to sign out or contact support. The /account/profile link simply allows you to edit your name and email address and save the changes. The problem link is **/account/plans**. It opens a pop up that just says "Choose a Plan" with a "Continue" button underneath. Hitting continue pops up a "Failed to process checkout..." message. This link should go to a 404.

Same Day Registration

In every national election several million voters are unable to vote due to problem with their voter registration.

One group are young voters, first-time voters, or those that have moved recently that miss their state’s deadline to register. Deadlines set weeks in advance of the election before Leaving many voters that don’t decide to vote until days before the election

A larger group are already registered voters turned away due to by a fixable error in their registration or incorrectly purged from the file. Among millions of new or updated registrations, mistakes are inevitably made by a clerk, third party registration drive, government agency, or the voter. Purges done to clean the state voter rolls can accidentally remove voters whose registration is valid.

How it Works

Same day registration, also known as Election Day registration, is a time-tested policy of First implemented by Maine, Minnesota, and Wisconsin in the 1970s. It allows voters with valid ID and proof of residency to register or update their registration when they vote on Election Day or during the early voting period Today there is no reason any state should let a fixable registration issue prevent citizens of voting age from voting.

Benefits

  • No voter is turned away by fixable voter registration issues. Voters still have a chance to register or correct a mistake in a previous registration when they vote. This is especially beneficial for first-time voters.

  • It Increases accuracy of registration rolls. Unlike registrations mailed in or done online, same day registrations are done in person by trained election officials

  • Saves the added cost of and uncertainty of using provisional ballots now used for voters not properly on the list.

  • This voter friendly policy has long been cited in political science research as likely to increase voter turnout by three to seven percentage points once implemented, even after controlling for other factors.

Automatic Voter Registration

Nearly a quarter of all eligible voters are not registered to vote. Among those that are registered, about one in eight have registration records that are invalid or have serious errors. Many of these errors are a result of first-time voters registering on their own, without access to accurate guidance, and often making mistakes.

Registration drives by schools, nonprofits, and campaigns and online tools all help enroll new voters. Automatic Voter Registration (AVR), at the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) reaches more people not otherwise likely to register and contributes to more complete and more accurate voter rolls.

A 2019 study by the Brennan Center found that the AVR policy increased the number of registrants, ranging anywhere from 15 to 94 percent in seven states that had implemented AVR long enough to measure results. As of 2020 the U.S. Census reported the greatest number of people currently use their Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) to register to vote, more than any other method.

How it Works

AVR takes advantage of all routine interactions at DMVs to automatically enroll eligible voters that are not currently registered, unless they opt out. For those already registered, it updates their registration to reflect a change of name or address. In some states it is also done at other government agencies that can confirm the voter’s residency and citizenship.

Most AVR states allow the person to opt out during the transaction, if they so choose. In some states like Oregon and Alaska, this is done later in response to a letter confirming their new registration.

AVR is best paired with Same Day registration so voters can update their registration if the voter’s address changes closer to the election.

Benefits

  • Once a person is registered and on their state’s voter roll, they are more likely to be contacted by their local election office, a campaign, or a community organization about when and where to vote and what’s on the ballot.
  • It is especially helpful for young voters under 30.

Mail Ballots and Early Voting In-Person

In 2020, for the first time ever, more people used mail ballots or early in-person voting than filled out a ballot at the polls on Election Day.

When asked why they chose these methods, the majority cited convenience and familiarity rather than COVID as the reason; with most stating that they would vote the same way in the next election.

As more voters choose to voter early, states should continue to expand and improve both options.

Mail ballots are still known in half the states as absentee ballots. Mail ballots started in the Civil War to accommodate soldiers absent from their voting location. More recently, as some states began sending all voters their ballot ahead of the election, it began to be known as vote-by-mail. In 2020 there were four main ways states provided access a mail ballot. The first three didn’t require voters to have an excuse to use one.

1. Sent a mail ballot to all registered voters in advance of the election, with multiple options to return their ballot at a drop box, poll or vote center, or by mail. (10 states)

2. Sent an application for a mail ballot to all registered voters. (12 states)

3. Voters got their application and returned it on their own online, at their election office, or by other means. (20 states)

4. Voters needed an excuse or special permission to apply for a mail ballot. (8 states)

  • Voters have more time to learn what’s on the ballot and consider their choices.
  • Voters become better informed on “down ballot” races, such as contests for the state legislature, county offices, or ballot measures that don’t have the same visibility of a race like president, governor, or congress.

Two-thirds of the states provide early voting at designated locations. Sites are staffed by election officials to allow voters to vote in-person or drop off a mail ballot in advance of Election Day.

States and their jurisdictions vary on the number of days, days of the week, hours, and locations offered. A jurisdiction can begin early voting for walk-ins as soon as the official ballots are available.

Benefits of Early Voting In-Person

  • It’s a good option for any voter wanting to avoid the risk of a health, family, work or transportation problem that might happen on Election Day. Many voters have made early voting in person a tradition.
  • It benefits voters who prefer to vote early with an election official and the same voting equipment used at the polls.
  • It reduces lines for voters and overload for election officials on Election Day.

More than 35 states used drop boxes in the 2020 election. They have proven to be a secure and convenient way to deliver your mail ballot to an election office before Election Day - popular with both voters and election officials.

Drop boxes are a secure, locked structure operated by election officials where voters may drop off their signed ballots in sealed envelopes leading up to Election Day. They are sited in convenient, accessible locations in or near public buildings, shopping areas, or college campuses, and the like. Staffed drop boxes are typically available during regular business hours and monitored by trained workers. Unstaffed drop boxes are monitored by cameras, are typically available 24 hours a day, and are permanently anchored in place.

Benefits of Drop Boxes

  • A good option, if you are not sure the post office will deliver it to the election office on time. They give the voter more confidence that their ballot will be processed and counted.
  • Eliminates the risk that a ballot returned by mail could be misplaced or delayed.
  • Election offices get them sooner with more time to prepare them to be counted.
