Non-Partisan Election Administration

One of the bedrock principles of holding an election is that it is run on a nonpartisan, impartial basis. As it stands, that’s true for all advanced democracies except the United States. One reason is that our Constitution gave away most election administration to the states without establishing any national standards for impartiality. Since 2020, six states—Alabama, Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, and Oklahoma—have passed new laws that open the door to partisan inter­fer­ence in elec­tions and/or threaten the people and processes that make elec­tions work.

Impartial election administration does still occur in practice. In the 2020 election, we saw top election officials resist outside pressure to change the final count, and the state electors were certified to decide the presidential election. Fortunately, these officials followed nonpartisan principles, drawing on their professional commitment to impartiality based on their understanding of the oath they took to uphold their state constitution. But nowhere are there national standards for impartiality built into the administrative design.

Today, in most states, the position of chief election official is held by the secretary of state, who is elected and takes office aligned with a political party. Recently, partisanship has been on the rise. In 2020, the Election Reformers Network and the Campaign Legal Center issued a report, “Guardrails for the Guardians,” that found since 2000:

  • Of the 137 elected secretaries of state serving between 2000 and 2020, 46 made at least one public endorsement for a candidate running in a race under their supervision.
  • 12 served as a co-chair of a presidential election campaign.
  • 153 sitting secretaries of state have run for office without any available evidence that the secretary took any public step to be recused from any conflict of interest, such as overseeing their own re-election or election to a higher office.
  • At the same time, the political action committees of the Democratic and Republican Associations of Secretaries of State weighed in on elections through fundraising, endorsements, and electioneering.

Ten states have nonpartisan election boards or commissions to run elections. A step forward, though done largely to balance the interests of the two major parties.

How it Should Work: Recommendations

The Election Reformers Network, made up of past election administrators, recommends that states:

  • Separate the election function from the office of the secretary of state and into a new dedicated entity. For example, a more neutral and apolitical version of current U.S. state election boards or commissions.
  • Include on these election boards members who are politically independent.
  • Consider calling on retired judges as is often done in other countries for this purpose.
  • Add or incorporate an oath of impartiality to be taken by those most responsible for election administration.
  • Prohibit partisan actions by secretaries of state and election board members, such as public endorsements of candidates running for office, accepting campaign positions for candidates or ballot questions, and fundraising and electioneering for or against any candidate.

Benefits

  • National standards for nonpartisanship set a clearer roadmap for all states to follow for national and state elections.
  • Removing the cloud of partisan intervention in elections that undermines public trust in elections and government.
  • Standard oaths of office for secretaries of state or other election officials would make commitments to impartiality more explicit.

Impartial election administration doesn’t guarantee confidence in fair elections. But keeping elections under partisan control will guarantee that the public’s declining trust in voting and elections will continue. Election administrators held the line in 2020; 2022 will be the next test.

https://electionreformers.org/impartial-election-admnistration/

https://electionreformers.org/guardrails-report/

https://law2.wlu.edu/deptimages/Law%20Review/62-3Hasen.pdf

posts.html:
Voting Rights Restoration

The U.S. is alone among advanced democracies in withholding the right to vote from people with felony convictions after their release from prison and re-entry into civic life. While nearly half the states allow voting on release, half continue to bar three million people on probation or parole from voting.

Post-prison voting restrictions undermine the core goals of probation and parole meant to rehabilitate offenders and guide them back into society while minimizing the likelihood that they will commit a new offense. As the American Probation and Parole Association said, “disenfranchisement laws work against the successful reentry of offenders.”

Disenfranchisement laws differ wildly among states. Misunderstood by voters and election officials, they end up being costly to maintain and accurately administer. As a result, thousands of eligible voters with any past conviction don’t vote, wrongly believing they’d break the law if they did, while others, unaware of their state’s prohibition, may be arrested for voting.  For example, Crystal Mason was sentenced to five years in prison for casting a provisional ballot mistakenly given to her by a poll worker in Texas.

Brief History

Disenfranchisement laws imported from England were repurposed by ten confederate states to limit the political voice of Black Americans granted citizenship and the right to vote after the Civil War and the 13th and 14thAmendments. More states would follow. Today, these laws continue to have the largest impact on African-Americans, who are four times more likely than all other racial groups to lose their voting rights.

Benefits

There are multiple benefits for the individual and society to allowing people to vote as soon as they exit prison include a more successful re-entry into community life and better citizenship, lower recidivism rates, reduced crime, and greater public safety.

  • More successful rehabilitation and re-entry

    In line with the purpose of probation and parole to facilitate the successful reintegration, people who vote are more likely to volunteer, gain employment, stay informed on local affairs, and contribute to their neighborhood in other ways.

  • Better citizenship

    The field’s most published sociologists, Christopher Uggen and Jeff Manza, observe, the “restoration of voting rights provides a clear marker of reintegration and acceptance as a stakeholder in a community of more law-abiding and engaged citizens.”

  • Lower recidivism rates

    Studies show people who vote are less likely to commit new crimes. In Minnesota, young offenders who became voters were half as likely to commit crimes and be rearrested. In Oregon recidivism was cut by 25% among people on probation and parole who voted. The Florida Parole Commission saw the recidivism rate reduced by almost two-thirds for those whose voting and civil rights were restored.

  • Increased public safety

    The reduced crime and better citizenship that comes with voting enhances public safety. Voting encourages people to invest in their communities by allowing them to participate as citizens and have a voice in issues that affect them. When asked about ending post-release voting restrictions, Minnesota Corrections Commissioner Paul Schnell said, “What makes us safer is having people be engaged.”

Conclusion

Marrying voting with our criminal justice system has always been problematic. Withholding the vote from those rebuilding their lives on probation or parole is neither practical nor does it advance any public interest for the either the person or the communities they return to. Regardless of the offense, society needs everyone convicted of a crime to change their behavior for the better.

Resources

Nonprofit VOTE: Policies by state for voting rights for people with felony convictions

https://www.nonprofitvote.org/voting-in-your-state/voting-as-an-ex-offender/

Campaign Legal Center: Look up tool on “Can I vote with a felony conviction in my state?"

https://campaignlegal.org/restoreyourvote

Brennan Center for Justice: Overview

https://www.brennancenter.org/issues/ensure-every-american-can-vote/voting-rights-restoration/disenfranchisement-laws

The Sentencing Project: Overview

https://www.sentencingproject.org/ issues/voting-rights/

States Restoring Voting Rights on Release from Prison

25 states continue to bar voting after prison for people on probation, parole, or any type of supervised release. In some states people can lose their voting rights permanently.

25 states and D.C. restore voting rights to all citizens with a felony conviction immediately on release from prison.

  • California
  • Colorado
  • Connecticut
  • District of Columbia*
  • Hawaii
  • Illinois
  • Indiana
  • Maine*
  • Maryland
  • Massachusetts
  • Michigan
  • Montana
  • Nevada
  • New Hampshire
  • New Jersey
  • New York
  • North Carolina
  • North Dakota
  • Ohio
  • Oregon
  • Pennsylvania
  • Rhode Island
  • Utah
  • Vermont*
  • Virginia
  • Washington

* Maine, Vermont, and the District of Columbia also allow people in prison for a felony to vote.
